title: Hewett Advances in Singles but Falls Short in Doubles at Australian Open
summary: Alfie Hewett, a top-seeded British wheelchair tennis player, has advanced to the men's wheelchair singles semi-finals at the Australian Open by defeating his compatriot and doubles partner Gordon Reid. The match, held on Margaret Court Arena, lasted one hour and 33 minutes, with Hewett winning 6-2, 6-3. This victory brings him closer to defending his singles title from last year, which was his 10th Grand Slam singles title overall. In the semi-finals, Hewett will face Spain's Martin de la Puente, who beat France's Stephane Houdet. However, in the doubles event, Hewett and Reid's quest for a seventh consecutive Australian Open doubles title ended with a loss in the semi-finals to Japan's Tokito Oda and Argentina's Gustavo Fernandez, with a score of 6-4, 2-6, 10-4 in a match tie-break. The British pair had previously dominated the doubles format, winning 18 of the last 23 Grand Slam titles. Meanwhile, in the quad doubles, Great Britain's Andy Lapthorne and Australia's Heath Davidson secured a spot in the final after a tight semi-final match. The article highlights Hewett's mixed results, emphasizing his ongoing success in singles and the end of a dominant doubles streak.
